title: Publications
text:
üü¢ PLoS ONE
Lucaci, A. G., Wisotsky, S. R., et al.¬†(2021).
Extra base hits: Widespread empirical support for instantaneous multiple-nucleotide changes.
https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0248337



Abstract

This study provides empirical evidence supporting the occurrence of instantaneous multiple-nucleotide substitutions across diverse datasets. The findings challenge assumptions of single-nucleotide substitution models and highlight implications for evolutionary inference.






üîµ Molecular Biology and Evolution
Wisotsky, S. R., Kosakovsky Pond, S. L., Shank, S. D., & Muse, S. V. (2020).
Synonymous site-to-site substitution rate variation dramatically inflates false positive rates of selection analyses: ignore at your own peril.
https://doi.org/10.1093/molbev/msaa037



Abstract

This paper demonstrates that ignoring synonymous rate variation can dramatically inflate false positive rates in selection analyses. The study emphasizes the importance of incorporating realistic rate heterogeneity into evolutionary models.



üü¢ PLoS ONE
Mannino, F., Wisotsky, S. R., Kosakovsky Pond, S. L., & Muse, S. V. (2020).
Equiprobable discrete models of site-specific substitution rates underestimate the extent of rate variability.
https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0229493



Abstract

This work shows that commonly used discrete substitution models underestimate true rate variability across sites, potentially biasing evolutionary inference and model-based conclusions.



üîµ Molecular Biology and Evolution
Kosakovsky Pond, S. L., Wisotsky, S. R., Escalante, A., et al.¬†(2020).
Contrast-FEL: A test for differences in selective pressures at individual sites among clades.
https://doi.org/10.1093/molbev/msaa263



Abstract

Contrast-FEL introduces a statistical method to test for differences in selective pressures at individual sites across clades, enabling more refined evolutionary hypothesis testing.



üîµ Molecular Biology and Evolution
Kosakovsky Pond, S. L., Poon, A. F. Y., Wisotsky, S. R., et al.¬†(2020).
HyPhy 2.5 - A Customizable Platform for Evolutionary Hypothesis Testing.
https://doi.org/10.1093/molbev/msz197



Abstract

HyPhy 2.5 provides a flexible, extensible computational framework for evolutionary hypothesis testing using phylogenies, supporting a broad range of statistical methods in molecular evolution.



üü£ bioRxiv (Preprint)
Cui, R., Tyers, A. M., Juzar Malubhoy, Z., Wisotsky, S. R., et al.¬†(2020).
Genomics of a killifish from the Seychelles islands supports transoceanic island colonization and reveals relaxed selection of developmental genes.
https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.08.03.232421



Abstract

This genomic study of a Seychelles killifish species provides evidence supporting transoceanic island colonization and identifies signatures of relaxed selection in developmental genes.






üü° Phytopathology
Parker, J. K., Wisotsky, S. R., et al.¬†(2014).
Viability of ‚ÄòCandidatus Liberibacter asiaticus‚Äô prolonged by addition of citrus juice to culture medium.
https://doi.org/10.1094/PHYTO-10-13-0264-R



Abstract

This study demonstrated that addition of citrus juice to culture media prolongs viability of ‚ÄòCandidatus Liberibacter asiaticus‚Äô, contributing to improved experimental approaches for studying this plant pathogen.

title: About
text:
Hi, I‚Äôm Sadie (Sarah) Rose Wisotsky, a passionate, data-driven bioinformatician with expertise in next-generation sequencing genomic data, data visualizations, and AI/ML techniques. Skilled in clinical trial data analysis, bioinformatics tool development, and cross-functional team collaboration. Proficient in leading teams, developing backend infrastructure, and delivering actionable insights through advanced data analysis and visualization techniques. In my free time I play roller derby, Dungeons and Dragons,
I‚Äôve worked on clinical trials data at phase I, II, III and pre-clinical. I‚Äôve touched oncological, virlogical
Here you‚Äôll find examples of projects I‚Äôve done for work, past workshops, and for fun.

title: Hyphy tutorials
text:
As part of my time as a postdoc at IGEM in Temple University, I recorded a series of youtube video for the HyPhy software package.
This video describe how to use BUSTED[S], a model I developed in graduate school while at NCSU. The paper for which can be read here.

The rest of the tutorial videos can be found on the HyPhy Youtube.
